Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis of Seismicity Associated with the Mw=8.8 2010 Maule Earthquake and Implications for Subduction Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mw=8.8 Maule earthquake off the coast of Chile on
February 27, 2010 is the 5th largest megathrust earthquake ever to be recorded and the 2nd
largest to be recorded by modern digital seismic networks. Immediately following the
Maule earthquake, teams of seismologists from Germany, France, the UK, and the US,
working with seismologists in Chile, coordinated resources to deploy both broadband and
short period seismometers and accelerometers above the rupture zone to capture
aftershocks associated with this significant earthquake. Data recorded from these stations
will be combined to produce an open international community data volume providing an
unprecedented opportunity to investigate processes associated with great earthquakes and
to image the anatomy of a subduction zone. A defining characteristic of the Maule aftershock investigations
has been collaboration, at both national and international levels. The original involvement
in the data collection by US teams grew voluntarily out of the IRIS community, and the
rationale of greater efficiencies through cooperation was readily adapted by the five
international groups working in the region.

In this project the researchers will carry out a broad but
interrelated spectrum of seismic analyses to the Maule international seismic data set,
along with a reanalysis of a selection of data collected in the rupture zone prior to the
earthquake, to address some of the fundamental scientific objectives that motivated the
initial data collection. These objectives fall into two general categories: (1) rupture
processes of megathrusts, and (2) active tectonics and dynamics of an oceanic-continental
(Andean) margin. They intend to produce an internally consistent set of data products across a range of
analytical techniques. The PIs will share graduate students and scheduling extended visits to each others labs, thereby exposing students to a significantly broader range of experience than most students typically enjoy. Finally, they plan to engage our international colleagues by sharing some analysis tasks of mutual
interest. Data products generated by this study will be made available to the broader
international community via a dedicated web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imaging the Slab and Forearc above the 2010 Maule Earthquake in Central Chile

Intellectural Merit: The Mw=8.8 Maule earthquake that occurred off the coast of Chile on February 27, 2010 is the 6th largest megathrust earthquakes ever to be recorded and ruptured ~600 km of the subduction zone plate boundary. This segment of the Nazca-South America plate boundary is an ideal region to investigate the processes related to the structure of the forearc wedge, continental Moho and subducting slab because of all the seismic data recorded following the Maule earthquake. Within weeks of the Maule earthquake, international teams joined Chilean seismologists to install an array of seismic stations between 33°- 38.5ºS, from the coast to the foothills of the Andes to produce the International Maule Aftershock Deployment (IMAD) dataset. Our goal was to locate aftershocks and image the Earth structure around the region of the Maule earthquake rupture. We used the IMAD data to locate aftershocks and determine seismic images of the subduction zone and region (slab and forearc) above the 2010 Maule earthquake rupture.

We imaged the subducted slab and forearc as well as parts of the active volcanic arc along the south central Chile margin. We produced both trench parallel and trench perpendicular cross-sections of seismic discontinuities using receiver functions.  In our trench parallel cross-sections near the Chile coast we image the down-going oceanic Moho.  In addition, we see a discontinuity indicating a decrease in velocity that we interpret as the base of the slab (oceanic lithosphere asthenosphere boundary) indicating the oceanic slab is ~50-60 km thick. Near the initiation of the Maule earthquake the slab is disrupted and is interpreted to be faulted or imbricated near a depth of ~40 km.

We produced a complete cross-section of seismic discontinuities across the entire Andes at ~36ºS.  We see a series of discontinuities beneath the arc that we interpret as the deep-crustal magma zone of melting, assimilation, storage and homogenization (MASH) zone. The 3 volcanoes in the region Descabezado Grande, Cerro Azul, and Laguna del Maule are some of the most active volcanoes in Chile and the MASH zone forms the source of the magma for these volcanoes.  Laguna del Maule shows a high rate of inflation at the surface and is located above the region where we image a MASH zone. In order to get a better image of seismic velocities in the forearc we used ambient noise tomography. We observe fast shear-wave velocities in the forearc and slow shear-wave velocities beneath the active volcanic arc. At shallow depths (5 km) we observe slow shear-wave velocities in several backarc basins.  At 20 km depth the forearc shear wave velocities are segmented at ~35.5°S. 

Broader Impacts: This project serves as an example of international collaboration using open data collected by the community after a major earthquake.  We helped organize a workshop held in Chile in 2013 on the anniversary of the magnitude 8.8 Maule earthquake that brought together scientists from around the world to discuss results and lessons learned from the Maule earthquake.  This project helped to train one MS graduate student and contributed to the training of 2 PhD students. Results of this project have been disseminated in presentations at national and international meetings and workshops and through scientific publications.
